quote: All right, Morn.  You know the rules.     No sleeping on the Promenade.  Go    home.
The risk is to you, Lieutenant.
I could probably think better without    your hand on my thigh.
Now, how did that get there?
So what's it gonna be?  Confront?     Evade?  Acquire?  Retreat?
Confront.
Yes.
Doesn't she ever lose?
(gazing with admiration     at Dax)   Tell me, Lieutenant, how did you get    to be so good at tongo?
Actually, Curzon used to play it all    the time.
Well, that explains it.  It's Curzon    who's beating us, not this female.
This female happens to be a better    player than Curzon ever was.
And a prettier one too.
Maybe so.  But I still prefer a    Ferengi female.       One who never wears clothes, never    talks back, and never plays tongo.
Is that how you really prefer your    women?  Naked and submissive.
Do you find such a lifestyle    appealing?
Don't you wish.
Oh I do.  I really do.
All right everyone.  The opening    risk is five strips of latinum.  The    purchase is at three.  The sell at    eight.
No, absolutely not.  This isn't the    proper time.
I'm trying to concentrate.
I'm sorry, Brother.       It's this insolent young waiter's    fault.
My apologies, Quark.  But I really    think you should try this.
What is it?
A way to double your beverage profits.     Taste it.
You see.       Just as I told you.  He immediately    reached for his drink.
So I did.
Amazing.  You don't even realize    you're thirsty.  What are they?

Gramilian Sand Peas.  They inhibit    secretion of the salivary glands    while drying out the tissues of the    tongue.  Works every time.  You    replace your complimentary dishes of    lokar beans with sand peas and you    won't be able to fill your customers'    glasses fast enough.
What's your name again?
Pel... so what do you think about my    idea?
I think I agree with the fifty-ninth    Rule of Acquisition, "Free advice is    seldom cheap."
True, but the twenty-second rule    says, "A wise man can hear profit in    the wind."
I see you know your Rules.
All two hundred and eighty-five of    them.  And the various commentaries    as well.       I don't plan on being a waiter    forever.
Good.  Then you're fired.
Shut up, Rom.       When it comes to business, my brother    has the weak little lobes of a female.       So what made you take a job here at    the station?
I wanted to learn from the best.
Which brings to mind the thirty-third    Rule of Acquisition...
"It never hurts to suck up to the    boss."
What's that?
It's Grand Nagus Zek's personal    subspace frequency.
I wonder what he wants.
Why do you look so surprised?  I    told you I'd be back.
I've looked forward to your return,    Nagus.
Still the perfect little toady, eh,    Quark?
I try to be.
Then listen carefully.  The Ferengi    expansion into the Gamma Quadrant is    about to begin.  I'd like you to be    my chief negotiator.
Me?
That's right.  I'm offering you an    opportunity to make more profit than    you ever dreamed of.       All you have to do is earn it.
Can I interest anyone in some Hupyrian    beetle snuff?
I don't think so.
Major?
No, thank you.
Suit yourself... more for me.
(grabs it out of his     hand)   A little late, aren't we?
So, you wanted to see me, Commander?
I understand that you're planning to    host a business conference here at    the station.
With the Dosi, a race from the Gamma    Quadrant.  A very profitable    opportunity for all concerned, I    might add.
Profitable for the Ferengi, maybe.
Are you implying something, Major?
Me?  Not at all.  The Ferengi's    reputation speaks for itself.
A reputation of honesty, decency,    and reliability.  You always know    what to expect when you do business    with the Ferengi.
Which is why, if you're smart, you    don't do business with the Ferengi...
I think you've made your point, Major.
As misinformed and misguided as it    may be.  Besides, how we do business    is none of your concern.
Except when you conduct your business    on this station.

In other words, Zek, Grand Nagus or    no Grand Nagus, if we allow you to    hold these negotiations here, and we    find out you're cheating these Dosi,    I'll see to it that you never set    foot on this station again.
Did anyone ever tell you your eyes    shine with the brilliance of Kibberian    fire diamonds.
Not that I recall.
Well they do.
Tell me, Major, could Bajor use fifty    thousand kilos of Brizeen nitrate?
Of course we could.  With that much    Brizeen, we could fertilize the entire    northern peninsula.
Well I've recently come into    possession of fifty thousand kilos    of Brizeen nitrate.  And to show you    how much your cooperation means to    me, I'll let you have the entire    shipment.
I'll still need your assurances that    the Dosi will be treated fairly while    they're here.
You have my word.       Then it's settled.       Let's see, that's fifty thousand    kilos at... twenty-five percent off    our usual price.
Twenty-five percent?  You just said    you were giving it to them.
You're right, Commander.  We're all    friends here.  I'll let you have it    at cost.
I have a better idea.  Why not    consider the nitrate a gift to the    people of Bajor.
A gift.  That doesn't sound very    profitable.
That depends.
On what?
On whether you want to conduct    business here or not.
Your negotiation skills aren't bad...    for a human.
Your nitrate will be delivered    promptly.  Anything else you need,    please come see me personally.
You know Quark, I've been involved    in some profitable opportunities in    my time.  But my lobes are telling    me this may be the most profitable    opportunity in Ferengi history.
Imagine that.  And part of those    profits will be mine.
Profit.  Fame.  Power.  As much as    you want.
Tell me, Nagus, what exactly is this    great opportunity.
I can sum it up in one word...    tulaberries.
(not what he expected     to hear)   Tulaberries?
Exactly.
Go on.
They're the main ingredient in    tulaberry wine.  Your job is to    purchase ten thousand vats from the    Dosi.
We're going into the wine business?
Within a year we'll have made    tulaberry wine the most popular drink    in their entire sector.
That's enough.
Yes, I like it.  Very distinguished.
Tell me, Nagus, how are tulaberries    going to be the most profitable    opportunity in Ferengi history?
Do I have to spell it out for you?
If you don't mind...
The tulaberries establish a Ferengi    presence inside the Gamma Quadrant.     And once we get our foot in the door,    they'll never get it out.
Yes, I see...
(with a conspiratorial     smile)   Tulaberries, Quark.  Tulaberries.
Tulaberries?  I wonder what they    taste like?
Who cares what they taste like.     They're an opportunity to get a    Ferengi foot in the Gamma Quadrant    door.
And it'll be your foot, brother.     I'm so proud.
I'm going to make history, Rom.  And    I'm going to be rich.       And I have the Grand Nagus to thank    for it.  He must really like me.
Just remember one thing, "The bigger    the smile, the sharper the knife."
The forty-eighth Rule of Acquisition.
I'd keep it in mind if I were you.
He has some nerve.
I warned you about that fellow.
You mind telling me what you meant    just now?
Did you ever think about why the    Nagus is putting you in charge of    such a lucrative opportunity?
Isn't it obvious?  He knows I have    the lobes for business.
That's only part of it.
I refuse to stand here and allow my    brother to be insulted.  You're fired.
Shut up.       Go on.
If these negotiations are profitable,    then the Nagus becomes a greater    hero than ever.  But if they fail,    he's going to need someone to take    the blame.
You mean me?
All I'm saying is be careful.
I never heard such ridiculous lies.     He's just jealous of your success,    Brother.
He's right.  If something goes wrong,    it'll be my fault.
Then you're going to need help,    Brother.
Yes.
Someone to serve as your consultant    during negotiations.
Yes.
Someone like me.
No.
I've been thinking about what you    said.  I probably could use some    help during these negotiations.
I accept.
Good.
Then we're partners.
Not quite.  I don't need a partner.     I need an assistant.
All right.  But I get twenty-five    percent of whatever you make.
Fifteen.
Twenty.
Done.
But Brother, what can I do to help.
You want to help?
Table Six is waiting.
How do I look?
Nervous.
Who me?  What do I have to be nervous    about?
It's Zek who should be nervous...    with Quark here as his chief    negotiator.
(forcing herself to     remain calm)   If you ever do that again...
Do what?
If you ever do that again, I'll stick    those fifty thousand kilos of    Brizeen...
Here they come.
Don't worry, just a minor    disagreement.
So, can I get anyone something to    eat?
All right, in that case, let's go    over our offer.
And in exchange, the Dosi will receive    what I consider a very fair trade    package.
There are some very interesting items    on that list.  A subspace field    modulator, some optical data    processors...
We'll give you five thousand vats.
I'm afraid that won't be enough.       We're looking to establish a vast    distribution network in the Gamma    Quadrant.  We're going to need at    least ten thousand vats.
I'm offering you five thousand vats.     I suggest you take it.
The Nagus will never agree.
This is a waste of time.  We should    be talking directly to Zek.
I know we should be talking to Zek.
Then why do you bother talking to    this insignificance?
Now see what you've done.
What?
You've made me look foolish.
I didn't mean to.
Then bring us Zek.
The Nagus has asked Quark to represent    him during these negotiations.
Are you implying that Zek is too    important to negotiate with us?
We never meant to imply...
Because if we kill you, then Zek    will have to talk to us.
You want to do business with the    Ferengi... you talk to Quark.
So, how about it?  Do we say ten    thousand vats?
We'll think about it.
Can I help you?
What is it?
It's beautiful.
It's latinum.
Excuse me.  I really can't accept    this.
Does Zek really think this was going    to get him anywhere?
Probably not.  But that doesn't stop    a Ferengi from trying.
You sound like you admire them for    it.
I suppose in a way I do.
(shakes her head in     amusement)   I don't understand this attitude you    have about the Ferengi.
That's because you don't socialize    with them the way I do.  Looking    back over seven lifetimes, I can't    think of a single race I've enjoyed    more.
Did anyone ever tell you that you    have very strange taste?
I admit they place too much emphasis    on profit, and their behavior toward    women is somewhat primitive...
They're greedy, misogynistic,    untrustworthy little trolls and I    wouldn't turn my back on one of them    for a second.
Neither would I.  But once you accept    that, you'll find they can be a lot    of fun.
Evade.
Evade.
Retreat.
Acquire.
Confront.
Did I say acquire?  I meant evade.
You said acquire.
But I meant evade.
Why don't we just play the round    over.
That sounds fair.
Who asked you?       And shouldn't you be plotting strategy    for tomorrow's negotiations?
Believe me, Nagus, I've thought about    nothing else all evening.
That must be why you're losing so    badly.
But I think by tomorrow we should    have an agreement.
Well I've been thinking, too, and    ten thousand vats of tulaberry wine    isn't enough.  Tell them we want a    hundred thousand.
A hundred thousand?  But I'm not    sure they'll even agree to sell us    ten thousand.
A hundred thousand vats will mean    more profit for them... and for us.       Now do as I say, or I'll take over    the negotiations myself.
I think raising the stakes is a    brilliant idea.
Do you?
It'll show the Gamma Quadrant we    mean business.  No wonder Quark says    you're a genius.
He says that, does he?
All the time.
That's very touching.
Now bring me some fresh tube grubs.     These are losing their crunch.
Right away.
I believe the next challenge goes to    you.
I think I'll pass on this round.
Such loyalty must be... expensive.
You can't buy that kind of loyalty.
You can where I come from.
Is the Nagus always this impatient?
He wants results.  And he expects me    to get them.  But he's not making my    job any easier.  A hundred thousand    vats... that's a lot of tulaberries.
You'll get them.
How can you be so sure?
Because you're good.  And with me    helping you, you're even better.
Why are you being so nice to me?
For twenty percent of your profits,    why else?
Fair enough.
Where are my grubs?
I didn't know the Replimat had a    Ferengi menu.
It doesn't.  I like to try new things.
That's unusual for a Ferengi.
I never heard of a Trill who played    tongo.
I guess that makes us both unusual.     You know I was impressed by your    show of loyalty to Quark last night.
He deserves it.
That's not the point.  Any other    Ferengi would have let Zek pick him    to pieces.       But you're not like any other Ferengi    I ever met.
You know Quark really likes you.  He    talks about you all the time.

He once convinced me to go up to a    holosuite with him.  Turns out he    had recreated the bedroom I slept in    as a child.  He overheard me    describing it to Kira.       Of course, he got most of the details    wrong, but it was a very sweet    gesture... up until he tried to kiss    me.
That sounds like Quark.
I don't care what anyone says, I    love him.
So do I.
You really do, don't you?
What?
Love Quark.  Don't bother denying    it.  I've seen the way you look at    him.
Keep your voice down.
Does he know?
He doesn't even know I'm a female.
You're a woman?
Would you please lower your voice?
I knew there was something different    about you.       I've never met a Ferengi woman before.
You probably never will again.  On    my world, women aren't allowed to    leave the house.  Or wear clothes.     Or learn to read.
And you want more.
Why not?  I'm as smart as any man.     So I made myself a pair of synthetic    lobes and became one.
But why come here?
To acquire profit, of course.       There's only one thing I hadn't    planned on.
Falling in love with Quark.
What do you think I should do?
I don't know.  But I do know there's    more to life than profit.
Pel... it's time.  We don't want to    keep the Dosi waiting.
Hurry!
Ah, Major, did your shipment of    Brizeen nitrate arrive on time?
Yes, it did.
Good.  And now you're here to thank    me.       Have a seat.
Actually, I just stopped by to return    this.
Why?  Is something wrong with it?
No, it's lovely.  I just can't accept    it.
Then I suppose a night of wild    passionate romance is out of the    question.
That's right.
Just thought I'd ask.
Dax must be crazy.
Nice view...
(continuing, re: the     Promenade)   ... isn't it.
Don't tell me the negotiations are    already over.  That's fast work,    Quark.  Now let's see the contract.
There is no contract.
No contract?  You offered to buy a    hundred thousand vats, didn't you?
Yes...
And?
And that's when they left.
The room?
The station.
What?
I begged them to stay.
He did.  I heard him.
This is a catastrophe.  A complete    catastrophe.
This was your big chance, Quark, and    you blew it.  You may have seriously    damaged future Ferengi opportunities    in the Gamma Quadrant.
Now hold on.  We said we'd get you    your tulaberries and that's exactly    what we're going to do.
We are?
How?
We'll travel to the Gamma Quadrant,    find the Dosi, and get them to sign    the contract.
And how do you plan to get there?
We'll take your ship.
My ship.  And I suppose you'd want    Maihar'du to pilot it for you.
We don't need Maihar'du.  I can pilot    the ship myself.
It's up to you, Nagus.  You want    those tulaberries or not?
All right.  You can use my ship.     But I'm warning you, Quark.  Either    you get the Dosi to sign that contract    or you'll be tending this worthless    little bar for the rest of your life.
I've waited my whole life for an    opportunity like this.
So have I.
So far it hasn't turned out quite    the way I planned.
It's not over yet.
I still don't understand why the    Nagus is suddenly insisting on a    hundred thousand vats.
Neither do I.
You don't think he's purposely trying    to sabotage the negotiations?
Why would he?
I have no idea.
One thing's for certain, he knows    more than he's letting on.
About what?
Everything.  Tulaberries, the Dosi,    even the Gamma Quadrant.
Well, if you ever figure out what    he's up to, make sure you tell me.
Don't worry, I will.
So far the only thing I've done right    is pick you as my consultant.
I'm glad you feel that way.
(turning his attention     back to the ship)   Now, if we could only make some    profit.
Quark, there's something you should    know.
You're too late.  I already know    what you're going to say.
You do?
It's no secret.
It's not?
I admit you've been a great help to    me... but you agreed to a twenty    percent share of the profits and    that's all you're going to get.
I see.
"Never place friendship above profit."
The twenty-first Rule of Acquisition.
I'm glad you agree.
Feeling a little overwhelmed are we?
I'm glad someone notices.
When's Quark due back?
How should I know?  He never tells    me anything.  He doesn't even bother    to insult me anymore.       It's Pel, that flabby eared    interloper.  He's stealing my    brother's affections.
You're better off.
But he's my brother.  Would you let    someone steal you're brother?
I don't have one.  Not that I know    of anyway.
But if you did?
I suppose if I did have a brother...    even one as worthless as Quark... I    wouldn't allow anyone to come between    us.
There must be something here I can    use against him.
Enjoying yourselves, little Ferengi?
How could we not.
Tell us, Zyree, what is this place.
This... this is where opportunities    are made.
Really?  I thought it was some kind    of party.
Then you thought wrong.    (gestures around the     room)   This is all about profit.  And like    the Ferengi, the Dosi are very serious    when it comes to profit.
Very serious.
(spotting someone     o.s.)   Look who finally showed up.
It's about time.
Where are you going?
To get serious about profit.
Oh, it's you, Ferengi.  Aren't you    on the wrong side of the wormhole?
It certainly feels that way.     Fortunately, all I need is your    thumbscan on this very lucrative    contract and I can go home.
You had your chance.
I said go away.
Not until we finish our discussion.
You're starting to annoy me.
Sorry.
I should have killed you back on    that station.
But you didn't.  Because deep down    inside you recognize a good    opportunity when you see one.       Just put your thumbscan here.
All right.  You can have ten thousand    vats.
A hundred thousand.
I told you before, that's impossible.
One hundred thousand and I'm not    leaving until I get it.
Fine.  Then stay.
Wouldn't we be more comfortable    sleeping on the ship?
No, I want to be right here in case    Inglatu changes his mind.       Don't worry.  I don't snore.
Wait.
What is it?
The mattress.
What about it?
It looks lumpy.
Actually, it's quite comfortable.
I can't sleep on a lumpy mattress.
Well, you're in luck.  There's not a    lump to be found.
Try it for yourself.  Which side to    you want?
What are you doing?
Getting undressed.  What's it look    like?
You're not going to sleep, are you?
Why not?  I'm tired.
But shouldn't we be discussing    strategy?
There's nothing to discuss.
But you know what the hundred and    third Rule of Acquisition says...
Not offhand.
"Sleep can interfere with... "
And I don't care either.
Wait.
What now?
First, a toast.
To what?
To profit, of course.
Of course.
Is it warm in here?
It must be the wine.
(nervously staring     into her eyes)   I hope so.
I was impressed with the way you    handled Inglatu.
I was good, wasn't I.       Now let's go to bed.
The look on his face when you knocked    over that barrel.
That was risky.
"The riskier the road, the greater    the profit."
The sixty-second Rule.
That's right.
(looking to fill the     silence)   You really know your Rules.
(swept away by the     moment)   And you have a very nice smile.
I do?
Quark, I have something to tell you...
I'm not interrupting anything, am I?
No.  Definitely not.
You're sure?
Positive.
I'll come back tomorrow.
Wait.
Don't be ridiculous, we can't wait    to hear what you have to say.     Besides, we could use the company.       Isn't that right.
Absolutely.
All right then, let me give you some    advice... Inglatu will never sell    you a hundred thousand vats of    tulaberry wine.  Not because he    doesn't want to, but because he can't.
If he can't, then who can?  You?
I wish I could, but there aren't    that many vats on the entire planet.
Then we're finished.
Not necessarily.       If you really want a hundred thousand    vats of tulaberry wine, I can put    you in touch with the right people.     For a price, of course.
Of course.       I always said you were my favorite    Dosi.       Now... who do we have to see?
The Karemma.
Who are the Karemma?
They're an important power in the    Dominion.
The Dominion?  What's that?
Let's just say that if you want to    do business in the Gamma Quadrant...    you have to do business with the    Dominion.

The biggest opportunity in Ferengi    history, that's what Zek called it.     But he didn't mean tulaberries.  He    meant the Dominion.  That's why he    sabotaged the negotiations.  He never    wanted to do business with the Dosi.     He just wanted to use them to get to    someone more important in the    Dominion.
Quark, we need to talk.
We are talking.
Don't you want to know why I kissed    you?
You didn't kiss me.
Yes, I did.

No, you didn't.  And I don't want to    discuss it anymore.       Now, let's just concentrate on the    Dominion.    (without waiting for     an answer)   I only wish Zyree would have told us    more.
It could be some kind of planetary    alliance; or trading consortium...
Whatever it is, it's important.  And    I want a piece of it.
I'm disappointed, Quark, very    disappointed.  I really wanted those    tulaberries.
You and I both know my trip had    nothing to do with tulaberries.
It didn't?
I must speak with you, Brother.
Can't you see I'm busy.
Does the word "Dominion" mean anything    to you.
What have you found out?
You first.
Please, Brother, it's urgent.
Not now.       I'm waiting.

Most of my information consists of    little more than hints and whispers,    but it's enough to convince me that    whoever learns the secret of the    Dominion, whatever it may be, will    learn the secret of the Gamma    Quadrant.       Unfortunately, the Dosi don't seem    to know very much.  I was hoping    they'd lead us to someone who does.
And what would such information be    worth to you?
A lot.
What if I told you I could arrange a    meeting between you and a powerful    member of the Dominion?
If you can do that, I'll see to it    that you earn a percentage of every    Ferengi opportunity in the Gamma    Quadrant.
That's a lot of latinum.
Give me a name.
The Karemma.
The Karemma.
I always knew you had the lobes for    business.
Now, may I have a word with you,    Brother.
All right.  But make it quick.
Easy now.  That's quite a bump you    have there.
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: Where's Rom?
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: Right here, Brother.
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: Luckily there doesn't seem to be any    serious damage.
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: If you don't mind, I'd like to rest    here for a few minutes.
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: Of course.  I'll be in the next room    if you need me.
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: Thank you, Doctor.
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: You haven't told anyone, have you?
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: You mean about Pel?
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: Quiet.
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: I haven't breathed a word.  I thought    it would be best if you told Zek    yourself.
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: No one's going to tell Zek anything.     Is that clear?
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: But she's a female...
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: Not so loud.
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: ... who wears clothes... and is trying    to earn profit... why she even quotes    from the sacred Rules of Acquisition.     Such a female must be severely    punished.
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: I know that.
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: Then we must stop her.
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: No.
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: You're scaring me, Brother.       Could it be you have feelings for    this woman?
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: Of course not.       Don't you see.  If Zek learns I was    deceived by a female, I'd be ruined.     He might never trust me again.
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: But, if you don't tell him and he    finds out, you're sure to be ruined.     You have to tell him, or I will.
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: Let me go.  I have to save you from    yourself.
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: Forget about me.       What about the bar?
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: The bar?
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: You still want it, don't you?
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: Don't you?
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: Who needs the bar when I can have    the Gamma Quadrant?  I'll transfer    ownership immediately... but only on    one condition.  You never mention    the truth about Pel to anyone.
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: Pel?  What about him?
scene: 64   INT. INFIRMARY - DAY - CLOSE ON QUARK

quote: Come.
Where are your lobes?
Over there.
Well, put them on, before someone    sees you.
No one's going to see me...
Put them on now.       And wrap yourself up.
Have you finished packing?
Am I going someplace?
As far away from this station as    possible.
I thought we were partners.
Not anymore.       Well, what did you expect?  I mean,    look at you, you're wearing clothes.
